SENT.plain: A seventeen year old boy sustained pelvic, femoral shaft and malleolar fractures in a road traffic accident
Six hours after admission, the patient became comatose (Glasgow coma score = 7); the coma worsened such that, 24 h later, the coma score was 4
Petechiae were present on the conjunctiva and anterior chest wall
Computed tomography revealed diffuse brain swelling
The diagnosis of cerebral fat embolism was made
There were multiple episodes of severe intracranial hypertension
After 23 days of traction, the femoral fracture was internally fixed
The patient returned home after five months of hospital, with just a few memory and writing problems
Ten months after the accident, magnetic resonance imaging showed a small ventricular dilatation due to subcortical atrophy
Residual ischaemic lesions and demyelination could be seen in the right centrum ovale and temporal lobe
The cerebral lesions contrast with the reversibility of the clinical state
